1â†’# PRD JSON Schema
     2â†’
     3â†’This document defines the canonical JSON structure for Product Requirements Documents (PRDs) in the Maven Flow system. All tools and agents must use this schema.
     4â†’
     5â†’## JSON Structure
     6â†’
     7â†’```json
     8â†’{
     9â†’  "project": "string - Project name from PRD title",
    10â†’  "branchName": "string - Git branch name in format: flow/feature-name-kebab-case",
    11â†’  "description": "string - Brief one-line description of the feature",
    12â†’  "memorialFile": "string - Path to memorial file: docs/memorial-feature-name.txt",
    13â†’  "relatedMemorials": [
    14â†’    "string - Paths to related memorial files"
    15â†’  ],
    16â†’  "userStories": [
    17â†’    {
    18â†’      "id": "string - User story ID: US-001, US-002, etc.",
    19â†’      "title": "string - Short title describing the story",
    20â†’      "description": "string - Full user story: As a [user], I want [feature] so that [benefit]",
    21â†’      "acceptanceCriteria": [
    22â†’        "string - Verifiable criterion 1",
    23â†’        "string - Verifiable criterion 2",
    24â†’        "string - Typecheck passes"
    25â†’      ],
    26â†’      "mavenSteps": [number, number],
    27â†’      "mcpTools": {
    28â†’        "step1": ["mcp-name-1", "mcp-name-2"],
    29â†’        "step7": ["mcp-name-3"]
    30â†’      },
    31â†’      "priority": number,
    32â†’      "passes": boolean,
    33â†’      "notes": "string"
    34â†’    }
    35â†’  ]
    36â†’}
    37â†’```
    38â†’
    39â†’## Field Specifications
    40â†’
    41â†’### Root Level
    42â†’
    43â†’| Field | Type | Required | Description |
    44â†’|-------|------|----------|-------------|
    45â†’| `project` | string | Yes | Project name, typically from PRD title |
    46â†’| `branchName` | string | Yes | Git branch name for this feature (format: `flow/feature-name`) |
    47â†’| `description` | string | Yes | One-line summary of what this feature does |
    48â†’| `memorialFile` | string | Yes | Path to this feature's memorial file |
    49â†’| `relatedMemorials` | array | Yes | List of related memorial file paths |
    50â†’| `userStories` | array | Yes | Array of user story objects (minimum 1) |
    51â†’
    52â†’### User Story Object
    53â†’
    54â†’| Field | Type | Required | Description |
    55â†’|-------|------|----------|-------------|
    56â†’| `id` | string | Yes | Story identifier: US-001, US-002, etc. |
    57â†’| `title` | string | Yes | Short descriptive title |
    58â†’| `description` | string | Yes | Full user story format: "As a [user], I want [feature] so that [benefit]" |
    59â†’| `acceptanceCriteria` | array | Yes | List of verifiable criteria. Must include "Typecheck passes" |
    60â†’| `mavenSteps` | array | Yes | Array of step numbers (1-10). Never empty. |
    61â†’| `mcpTools` | object | Yes | Step-based MCP tool mapping. Use `{}` if none. |
    62â†’| `priority` | number | Yes | Priority order (lower = higher priority). Must be â‰¥ 1. |
    63â†’| `passes` | boolean | Yes | Story completion status. Always `false` initially. |
    64â†’| `notes` | string | Yes | Implementation notes. Always empty string initially. |
    65â†’
    66â†’## Maven Steps Reference
    67â†’
    68â†’Every user story must specify which Maven Flow steps are required:
    69â†’
    70â†’| Step | Agent | Purpose |
    71â†’|------|-------|---------|
    72â†’| 1 | development | Foundation/UI from scratch |
    73â†’| 2 | development | Package manager changes (npmâ†’pnpm) |
    74â†’| 3 | refactor | Feature structure changes |
    75â†’| 4 | refactor | Modularization (when >300 lines) |
    76â†’| 5 | quality | Type safety enforcement (no 'any' types) |
    77â†’| 6 | refactor | UI centralization (@shared/ui) |
    78â†’| 7 | development | Data layer/backend implementation |
    79â†’| 8 | security | Authentication/authorization integration |
    80â†’| 9 | development | MCP integration |
    81â†’| 10 | security | Security hardening & error handling |
    82â†’
    83â†’### Step Mapping by Story Type
    84â†’
    85â†’- **Database changes** â†’ `[1, 7]`
    86â†’- **UI component** â†’ `[5, 6]`
    87â†’- **Backend API** â†’ `[1, 7, 10]`
    88â†’- **Auth flow** â†’ `[1, 7, 8, 10]`
    89â†’- **Full feature** â†’ `[1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 10]`
    90â†’
    91â†’## MCP Tools Format
    92â†’
    93â†’The `mcpTools` object maps step numbers to MCP server names:
    94â†’
    95â†’```json
    96â†’{
    97â†’  "mcpTools": {
    98â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
    99â†’    "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"]
   100â†’  }
   101â†’}
   102â†’```
   103â†’
   104â†’**Rules:**
   105â†’- Only list MCP **server names** (e.g., "supabase"), not individual tools
   106â†’- Use step-based keys: "step1", "step2", etc.
   107â†’- Use empty object `{}` if no MCPs needed for this story
   108â†’
   109â†’### Common MCPs
   110â†’
   111â†’| MCP Name | When to Use |
   112â†’|----------|-------------|
   113â†’| `supabase` | Steps 1, 7, 8, 10 - Database/auth operations |
   114â†’| `web-search-prime` | All steps - Web searches |
   115â†’| `chrome-devtools` | Testing - Browser automation |
   116â†’| `4-5v-mcp` | All steps - Image analysis |
   117â†’
   118â†’## Story Sizing Rules
   119â†’
   120â†’Each story MUST be completable in ONE iteration (one context window).
   121â†’
   122â†’### RIGHT-sized stories:
   123â†’- Add database column + migration
   124â†’- Add UI component to existing page

1â†’# Required MCPs for Maven Flow Projects
     2â†’
     3â†’This document specifies the **MANDATORY MCPs** that must be configured for Maven Flow projects to function correctly.
     4â†’
     5â†’---
     6â†’
     7â†’## Overview
     8â†’
     9â†’Maven Flow requires certain MCP servers to be available for autonomous development and testing. These MCPs are NOT optional - they are core to the workflow.
    10â†’
    11â†’---
    12â†’
    13â†’## Mandatory MCPs
    14â†’
    15â†’### 1. Supabase MCP (REQUIRED)
    16â†’
    17â†’**Purpose:** Direct database access, schema verification, migrations, and type generation.
    18â†’
    19â†’**Why it's mandatory:**
    20â†’- Agents need to QUERY the actual database (not read files)
    21â†’- Agents need to VERIFY tables and schema exist
    22â†’- Agents need to CREATE tables and run migrations
    23â†’- Agents need to GENERATE TypeScript types from live schema
    24â†’
    25â†’**Without Supabase MCP:**
    26â†’- Agents will fall back to reading migration files (doesn't verify actual database)
    27â†’- Agents will create migration scripts manually (error-prone)
    28â†’- Agents cannot verify what's actually in the database
    29â†’
    30â†’**Setup Instructions:**
    31â†’1. Install Supabase CLI: `npm install -g supabase`
    32â†’2. Configure MCP in Claude Code settings with your Supabase project
    33â†’3. Verify MCP is available: Check Claude Code MCP server list
    34â†’
    35â†’**Used by these Maven Steps:**
    36â†’- Step 1 (Foundation) - Create tables, verify schema
    37â†’- Step 7 (Data Layer) - Set up database, migrations
    38â†’- Step 8 (Auth) - Configure authentication
    39â†’- Step 10 (Security) - Verify RLS policies
    40â†’
    41â†’---
    42â†’
    43â†’### 2. chrome-devtools MCP (REQUIRED)
    44â†’
    45â†’**Purpose:** Live browser testing, console log reading, application verification.
    46â†’
    47â†’**Why it's mandatory:**
    48â†’- Testing-agent MUST open the application to test features
    49â†’- Agents MUST read console logs to find errors
    50â†’- Agents MUST verify UI works in real browser
    51â†’- Agents MUST test user flows end-to-end
    52â†’
    53â†’**Without chrome-devtools MCP:**
    54â†’- Testing-agent cannot test the application
    55â†’- Console errors go undetected
    56â†’- Features cannot be verified in browser
    57â†’- Testing becomes manual and incomplete
    58â†’
    59â†’**Setup Instructions:**
    60â†’1. Install chrome-devtools MCP in Claude Code
    61â†’2. Configure with browser path (Chrome/Chromium)
    62â†’3. Verify MCP can launch browser and navigate to pages
    63â†’
    64â†’**Used by these Maven Steps:**
    65â†’- Step 9 (MCP Integration) - Test browser automation
    66â†’- Testing-agent - Complete application testing
    67â†’
    68â†’---
    69â†’
    70â†’## How to Verify MCPs Are Configured
    71â†’
    72â†’**Before starting Maven Flow:**
    73â†’
    74â†’1. **Check Claude Code MCP Settings:**
    75â†’   - Open Claude Code Settings
    76â†’   - Go to MCP Servers section
    77â†’   - Verify "supabase" is in the list
    78â†’   - Verify "chrome-devtools" is in the list
    79â†’
    80â†’2. **Test MCPs are working:**
    81â†’   - Start a conversation
    82â†’   - Ask agent to list tables using Supabase MCP
    83â†’   - Ask agent to open browser using chrome-devtools MCP
    84â†’
    85â†’3. **If MCPs are missing:**
    86â†’   - DO NOT start `/flow start`
    87â†’   - Configure the missing MCP first
    88â†’   - Restart Claude Code
    89â†’   - Verify again
    90â†’
    91â†’---
    92â†’
    93â†’## MCP Enforcement in PRDs
    94â†’
    95â†’**When creating PRD JSON files, always include these MCPs:**
    96â†’
    97â†’```json
    98â†’{
    99â†’  "id": "US-001",
   100â†’  "title": "Create users table",
   101â†’  "mavenSteps": [1, 7],
   102â†’  "mcpTools": {
   103â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
   104â†’    "step7": ["supabase", "chrome-devtools"]
   105â†’  }
   106â†’}
   107â†’```
   108â†’
   109â†’**Rules:**
   110â†’- **ALL database stories** MUST include `"supabase"` in mcpTools
   111â†’- **ALL stories with UI/testing** MUST include `"chrome-devtools"` in mcpTools
   112â†’- **Step 9 (MCP Integration)** should list both MCPs
   113â†’
   114â†’---
   115â†’
   116â†’## Optional MCPs (Recommended but Not Required)
   117â†’
   118â†’These MCPs are useful but not mandatory:
   119â†’
   120â†’| MCP Name | Purpose | When to Include |
   121â†’|----------|---------|-----------------|
   122â†’| web-search-prime | Research documentation | All steps |
   123â†’| web-reader | Read web pages | All steps |
   124â†’| playwright | Browser automation testing | Testing phases |
   125â†’| wrangler | Cloudflare Workers deployment | Step 9 |
   126â†’| vercel | Vercel deployment | Step 9 |
   127â†’| figma | Design work | Step 11 (mobile) |
   128â†’
   129â†’**Only include these MCPs if:**
   130â†’- They are actually configured in your environment
   131â†’- The story specifically needs them
   132â†’- You've verified they're available
   133â†’
   134â†’---
   135â†’
   136â†’## Troubleshooting MCP Issues
   137â†’
   138â†’### Supabase MCP Not Working
   139â†’
   140â†’**Symptoms:**
   141â†’- Agent says "Supabase MCP not available"
   142â†’- Agent reads migration files instead of querying database
   143â†’- Type files don't match actual database
   144â†’
   145â†’**Solutions:**
   146â†’1. Check Supabase project is linked in MCP settings
   147â†’2. Verify project ID is correct
   148â†’3. Check MCP server is running
   149â†’4. Try restarting Claude Code
   150â†’
   151â†’### chrome-devtools MCP Not Working
   152â†’
   153â†’**Symptoms:**
   154â†’- Testing-agent cannot open browser
   155â†’- Agent says "browser automation not available"
   156â†’- Console logs cannot be read
   157â†’
   158â†’**Solutions:**
   159â†’1. Verify browser path in MCP settings
   160â†’2. Check Chrome/Chromium is installed
   161â†’3. Test MCP manually: "Open browser to http://localhost:3000"
   162â†’4. Restart Claude Code if needed
   163â†’
   164â†’---
   165â†’
   166â†’## Summary
   167â†’
   168â†’**MANDATORY MCPs (Must Have):**
   169â†’- âœ… supabase
   170â†’- âœ… chrome-devtools
   171â†’
   172â†’**OPTIONAL MCPs (Nice to Have):**
   173â†’- web-search-prime
   174â†’- web-reader
   175â†’- playwright
   176â†’- wrangler
   177â†’- vercel
   178â†’- figma
   179â†’
   180â†’**Before running `/flow start`:**
   181â†’1. Verify supabase MCP is configured
   182â†’2. Verify chrome-devtools MCP is configured
   183â†’3. Test both MCPs work correctly
   184â†’4. Only then start the flow
   185â†’
   186â†’**Remember:** Without these MCPs, Maven Flow cannot function as designed. Agents will fall back to less reliable methods (reading files instead of querying database, manual testing instead of automated browser testing).
   187â†’

     6â†’# Maven Flow PRD Converter
     7â†’
     8â†’Convert markdown PRD files to JSON format for Maven Flow processing.

    10â†’**CRITICAL: Always work in the current working directory (user's project root), NOT in the command installation directory.**
    11â†’- Use `$PWD` or `$(pwd)` to get the current working directory
    12â†’- Read PRD files from `./docs/prd-*.md`

    15â†’## Commands

    17â†’### Convert PRD to JSON

    24â†’**What happens:**
    25â†’1. Reads `docs/prd-[feature-name].md`

    30â†’   - Similar naming patterns in `docs/`
    31â†’   - Common integration points
    32â†’5. Creates `docs/prd-[feature-name].json` with:
    33â†’   - Boolean `passes` fields (true/false for each story)
    34â†’   - `relatedPRDs` array with paths to related PRD JSONs
    35â†’   - `consolidatedMemory` path (always points to THIS PRD's own memory file)
    36â†’   - Proper `mcpTools` mapping per step
    37â†’   - Schema version for future compatibility
    38â†’
    39â†’**Example usage:**
    40â†’```
    41â†’/flow-convert authentication
    42â†’```

    54â†’### Help

    87â†’      ],

   102â†’### Key JSON Fields

   104â†’| Field | Type | Description |

   131â†’## Related PRD Detection
   132â†’
   133â†’The converter intelligently detects related PRDs by analyzing:
   134â†’
   135â†’### 1. Feature Dependencies
   136â†’- **Authentication PRD**: Auto-detected when stories mention:
   137â†’  - "user", "login", "signup", "auth", "session"
   138â†’  - Protected routes, permissions
   139â†’- **Database PRD**: Auto-detected when stories mention:
   140â†’  - "table", "schema", "migration", "database"
   141â†’  - Supabase, PostgreSQL
   142â†’
   143â†’### 2. Naming Patterns
   144â†’Scans `docs/prd-*.md` files for similar keywords:
   145â†’- "dashboard" relates to "authentication" (requires auth)
   146â†’- "tasks" relates to "users" (has user_id foreign key)
   147â†’- "notifications" relates to "users" (sends to users)
   148â†’
   149â†’### 3. Integration Points
   150â†’- Features that share database tables
   151â†’- Features with API dependencies
   152â†’- UI components that reference other features
   153â†’
   154â†’### Related PRD Example
   155â†’
   156â†’**Dashboard PRD (depends on Authentication):**

   159â†’  "schemaVersion": 1,

   161â†’  "consolidatedMemory": "docs/consolidated-dashboard.txt",
   162â†’  "relatedPRDs": ["docs/prd-authentication.json"],
   163â†’  ...
   164â†’}
   165â†’```
   166â†’
   167â†’- Dashboard's `consolidatedMemory` points to ITS OWN memory
   168â†’- Dashboard's `relatedPRDs` points to Authentication PRD

   172â†’## Conversion Rules
   173â†’
   174â†’### 1. Boolean Status Fields
   175â†’
   176â†’**Markdown Status Field** (informational for humans):
   177â†’```markdown
   178â†’**Status:** false (informational - for humans)
   179â†’```
   180â†’
   181â†’**JSON passes Field** (authoritative for machines):
   182â†’```json
   183â†’"passes": false
   184â†’```
   185â†’
   186â†’- Use `true`/`false` (boolean), NOT "complete"/"incomplete"
   187â†’- The JSON `passes` field is the authoritative source
   188â†’- Markdown status is informational only
   189â†’
   190â†’### 2. Memory References
   191â†’
   192â†’**consolidatedMemory** (points to THIS PRD's memory):
   193â†’```json
   194â†’"consolidatedMemory": "docs/consolidated-[feature].txt"
   195â†’```
   196â†’
   197â†’- Always points to THIS PRD's OWN consolidated memory
   198â†’- Will be created AFTER all stories complete
   199â†’- Used by OTHER PRDs that depend on this one
   200â†’
   201â†’**relatedPRDs** (points to OTHER PRDs):
   202â†’```json
   203â†’"relatedPRDs": ["docs/prd-authentication.json"]
   204â†’```
   205â†’
   206â†’- Array of OTHER PRD JSON files
   207â†’- Used to load their consolidated memories
   208â†’- Enables cross-PRD context sharing
   209â†’
   210â†’### 3. MCP Tools Mapping
   211â†’
   212â†’Each step can specify different MCP tools:
   213â†’
   214â†’```json
   215â†’"mcpTools": {
   216â†’  "step1": ["supabase"],
   217â†’  "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"],
   218â†’  "step10": []
   219â†’}
   220â†’```
   221â†’
   222â†’- `step1`: Use supabase MCP
   223â†’- `step7`: Use supabase AND web-search-prime MCPs
   224â†’- `step10`: No specific MCPs required
   225â†’

     5â†’
     6â†’# Maven Flow
     7â†’
     8â†’Autonomous AI development flow that implements PRD stories using the Maven 10-Step Workflow. Supports multiple feature PRDs with automatic story tracking and completion.
     9â†’
    10â†’**Multi-PRD Architecture:** Each feature has its own `docs/prd-[feature-name].json` file. The flow automatically scans for incomplete PRDs and processes them in order.
    11â†’
    12â†’## Commands
    13â†’
    14â†’### Start a new flow
    15â†’```
    16â†’/flow start [max-iterations]
    17â†’```
    18â†’
    19â†’**CRITICAL: This command runs AUTOMATICALLY until ALL stories complete**
    20â†’
    21â†’**Architecture:** The `/flow` command (running in main Claude context) coordinates ALL specialist agent spawning directly. Subagents are NOT used for coordination since they cannot spawn other subagents.
    22â†’
    23â†’---
    24â†’
    25â†’## Prerequisites Check
    26â†’
    27â†’Before starting, the command validates:
    28â†’
    29â†’1. **`docs/` directory exists**
    30â†’   - If missing: `âŒ Error: No docs/ directory found.`
    31â†’   - Fix: Create the directory: `mkdir docs`
    32â†’
    33â†’2. **PRD files exist** (`docs/prd-*.json`)
    34â†’   - If missing: `âŒ Error: No PRD files found in docs/.`
    35â†’   - Fix: Create a PRD first using the `flow-prd` skill:
    36â†’     ```
    37â†’     Tell me you want to create a PRD for [feature]
    38â†’     Example: "Create a PRD for a user authentication feature"
    39â†’     ```
    40â†’
    41â†’3. **At least one incomplete story**
    42â†’   - If all PRDs complete: `âœ… All PRDs complete! No work to do.`
    43â†’   - Fix: Create a new PRD or add stories to existing PRD
    44â†’
    45â†’4. **Maven Flow wrapper script** (optional, for local execution)
    46â†’   - The flow can create `maven-flow.sh` locally for direct execution
    47â†’   - This wrapper is created automatically when needed
    48â†’   - If you encounter syntax errors, delete `maven-flow.sh` and let flow recreate it
    49â†’
    50â†’---
    51â†’
    52â†’When you execute `/flow start` or `/flow continue`:
    53â†’
    54â†’1. **Validate prerequisites** (docs/, PRD files, incomplete stories)
    55â†’2. Scan for incomplete PRDs
    56â†’3. Pick the first incomplete story
    57â†’4. **Spawn specialist agents directly using Task tool:**
    58â†’   - For each mavenStep in the story, spawn appropriate agent
    59â†’   - Tell agent which MCPs to use (from PRD mcpTools)
    60â†’   - Wait for agent to complete before spawning next
    61â†’   - Continue until all mavenSteps are done
    62â†’5. Run quality checks, commit, update PRD
    63â†’6. **Repeat automatically** for next story
    64â†’7. Continue until ALL PRDs have ALL stories passing
    65â†’8. Do NOT wait for user input between stories
    66â†’9. Do NOT stop after one story - keep going until ALL are complete
    67â†’
    68â†’**Example:**
    69â†’```
    70â†’/flow start 15
    71â†’```
    72â†’
    73â†’**How it works:**
    74â†’1. Scans for all `docs/prd-*.json` files
    75â†’2. For each PRD, checks if all stories have `passes: true`
    76â†’3. Finds the first PRD with incomplete stories
    77â†’4. For each incomplete story (in priority order):
    78â†’
    79â†’   **MEMORY LOADING PHASE:**
    80â†’   - Read PRD's `relatedPRDs` array
    81â†’   - Load consolidated memory from each related PRD (if any)
    82â†’   - Pre-analyze and summarize relevant sections (~3-5K tokens)
    83â†’   - Load previous story memories from same PRD (~10K tokens)
    84â†’   - Create story session with proper context structure
    85â†’
    86â†’   **IMPLEMENTATION PHASE:**
    87â†’   - Read story's mavenSteps array
    88â†’   - Read story's mcpTools (if specified for each step)
    89â†’   - **Spawn specialist agents directly:**
    90â†’     - Step 1, 2, 7, 9 â†’ Task(subagent_type="development-agent")
    91â†’     - Step 3, 4, 6 â†’ Task(subagent_type="refactor-agent")
    92â†’     - Step 5 â†’ Task(subagent_type="quality-agent")
    93â†’     - Step 8, 10 â†’ Task(subagent_type="security-agent")
    94â†’     - Step 11 â†’ Task(subagent_type="design-agent") [optional, for mobile apps]
    95â†’   - **Tell agent which MCPs to use with EXPLICIT INSTRUCTIONS at the start of prompt:**
    96â†’     ```
    97â†’     *** CRITICAL: MCP TOOLS INSTRUCTION ***
    98â†’     You MUST use the Supabase MCP tools for ALL database operations.
    99â†’     DO NOT read migration files or create scripts.
   100â†’     SCAN FIRST - Use MCP to list/check what exists in the database BEFORE making any changes.
   101â†’     Query the database DIRECTLY using Supabase MCP tools.
   102â†’
   103â†’     Story: US-POS-001, Step 1
   104â†’     MCPs: supabase
   105â†’     ```
   106â†’   - Wait for each agent to complete
   107â†’   - Run quality checks (typecheck, lint)
   108â†’
   109â†’   **MEMORY CREATION PHASE (MANDATORY - DO NOT SKIP!):**
   110â†’
   111â†’   This phase is CRITICAL for the memory system. You MUST execute it for EVERY completed story.
   112â†’
   113â†’   **Mandatory Steps:**
   114â†’   1. **Create feature folder:** `mkdir -p docs/[feature]/`
   115â†’   2. **Create story memory file:** `docs/[feature]/story-US-[###]-[title].txt`
   116â†’   3. **Include:**
   117â†’      - What was implemented (specific files, functions, components)
   118â†’      - Key decisions made (architecture choices, design patterns)
   119â†’      - Technical challenges encountered and how they were resolved
   120â†’      - Integration points with other features
   121â†’      - Lessons learned for future work
   122â†’   4. **Update PRD JSON:** Set `passes: true` for the completed story
   123â†’   5. **Commit changes** with proper format: `feat: [story-id] [story-title]`
   124â†’   6. **Output signal:** Output the `<STORY_COMPLETE>` signal to indicate completion
   125â†’
   126â†’   **Memory file format:**
   127â†’   ```markdown

   747â†’## MCP Tool Assignment
   748â†’
   749â†’### What are MCPs?
   750â†’MCPs (Model Context Protocol) extend Claude with external tools like databases, web search, and browser automation.
   751â†’
   752â†’### How MCP Assignment Works
   753â†’
   754â†’**1. PRD specifies MCPs per step:**
   755â†’```json
   756â†’{
   757â†’  "id": "US-001",
   758â†’  "mavenSteps": [1, 7],
   759â†’  "mcpTools": {
   760â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
   761â†’    "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"]
   762â†’  }
   763â†’}
   764â†’```
   765â†’
   766â†’**2. Flow tells agent which MCPs to use:**
   767â†’```
   768â†’*** CRITICAL: MCP TOOLS INSTRUCTION ***
   769â†’You MUST use the Supabase MCP tools for ALL database operations.
   770â†’SCAN FIRST - Use MCP to list/check what exists in the database BEFORE making changes.
   771â†’Query the database DIRECTLY using Supabase MCP tools.
   772â†’
   773â†’Story: US-001, Step 1
   774â†’MCPs: supabase
   775â†’```
   776â†’
   777â†’**3. Agent uses those MCPs:**
   778â†’- Checks if MCPs are available in their tool set
   779â†’- Uses MCP tools directly to query database, run migrations, etc.
   780â†’- Falls back to standard tools only if MCPs unavailable

   795â†’**MCP Usage Rules:**

   839â†’## How It Works
   840â†’
   841â†’### Multi-PRD Processing
   842â†’
   843â†’When you run `/flow start`:
   844â†’
   845â†’1. **Scan Phase:** The flow scans `docs/` for all `prd-*.json` files
   846â†’2. **Priority Phase:** For each PRD, checks completion status:
   847â†’   - Loads JSON and checks if all stories have `passes: true`
   848â†’   - Identifies PRDs with incomplete stories (`passes: false`)
   849â†’3. **Selection Phase:** Picks the first incomplete PRD (alphabetically by filename)
   850â†’4. **Iteration Phase:** Processes that PRD's stories one by one:
   851â†’   - Reads PRD JSON and picks highest priority story where `passes: false`
   852â†’   - Reads story's `mavenSteps` array
   853â†’   - **Spawns specialist agents directly** (one per mavenStep)
   854â†’   - Waits for each agent to complete
   855â†’   - Runs quality checks
   856â†’   - Commits changes
   857â†’   - Updates PRD to `passes: true`
   858â†’   - Appends learnings to progress file
   859â†’5. **Completion Phase:** When PRD is complete (all `passes: true`):
   860â†’   - Marks PRD as complete
   861â†’   - Moves to next incomplete PRD
   862â†’   - Repeats iteration phase
   863â†’6. **Final Phase:** When all PRDs are complete:
   864â†’   - Outputs completion summary
   865â†’

  1210â†’## Testing & Consolidation
  1211â†’
  1212â†’### Workflow: Test â†’ Log â†’ Consolidate â†’ Fix
  1213â†’
  1214â†’Maven Flow includes a systematic testing and error consolidation workflow to ensure quality.
  1215â†’
  1216â†’### Step 1: Test (`/flow test`)
  1217â†’
  1218â†’**Purpose:** Comprehensive automated testing of all completed features
  1219â†’
  1220â†’**What happens:**
  1221â†’1. Reads PRD to find completed stories (where `passes: true`)
  1222â†’2. Starts dev server: `pnpm dev`
  1223â†’3. Opens application using chrome-devtools MCP
  1224â†’4. Tests user signup/login with standard test credentials
  1225â†’5. Tests each completed feature's acceptance criteria
  1226â†’6. Checks console for errors (logs ALL errors found)
  1227â†’7. Tests navigation, forms, data display
  1228â†’8. Creates error log at `docs/errors-[feature-name].md`
  1229â†’
  1230â†’**Standard Test User:**
  1231â†’- Email: `revccnt@gmail.com`
  1232â†’- Password: `Elishiba!90`
  1233â†’
  1234â†’**What gets tested:**
  1235â†’- User authentication (signup, login, logout)
  1236â†’- All completed stories' acceptance criteria
  1237â†’- Console errors (JavaScript, network, API)
  1238â†’- UI functionality
  1239â†’- Navigation between pages
  1240â†’- Form submissions
  1241â†’- Data display
  1242â†’
  1243â†’**Example:**
  1244â†’```bash
  1245â†’/flow test task-priority
  1246â†’```
  1247â†’
  1248â†’**Output:**
  1249â†’- Shows which features are being tested
  1250â†’- Reports errors in real-time
  1251â†’- Creates error log markdown file
  1252â†’- Summary with error counts by severity
  1253â†’
  1254â†’### Step 2: Review Error Log
  1255â†’
  1256â†’**Error log format:** `docs/errors-[feature-name].md`
  1257â†’
  1258â†’**Each error includes:**
  1259â†’- Story ID (US-XXX)
  1260â†’- Severity (Critical / High / Medium / Low)
  1261â†’- Error type (Console Error / Network Error / UI Issue)
  1262â†’- Error message (exact text from console)
  1263â†’- Steps to reproduce
  1264â†’- Expected vs actual behavior
  1265â†’- Related file references
  1266â†’- Suggested fixes
  1267â†’
  1268â†’**Example error log entry:**
  1269â†’```markdown
  1270â†’## Error 1
  1271â†’
  1272â†’**Story:** US-003 - Add priority selector
  1273â†’**Feature:** Task creation form
  1274â†’**Severity:** High
  1275â†’
  1276â†’**Error Type:** Console Error
  1277â†’
  1278â†’**Error Message:**
  1279â†’```
  1280â†’Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'map' of undefined
  1281â†’at PrioritySelector.tsx:24
  1282â†’```
  1283â†’
  1284â†’**Steps to Reproduce:**
  1285â†’1. Navigate to /tasks/create
  1286â†’2. Click on "Priority" dropdown
  1287â†’3. Observe error in console
  1288â†’
  1289â†’**Expected Behavior:**
  1290â†’Priority dropdown shows options: Low, Medium, High, Urgent
  1291â†’
  1292â†’**Actual Behavior:**
  1293â†’Application crashes, dropdown doesn't render
  1294â†’
  1295â†’**Related Files:**
  1296â†’- File: src/features/tasks/components/PrioritySelector.tsx
  1297â†’- Line: 24
  1298â†’- Component: PrioritySelector
  1299â†’
  1300â†’**Suggested Fix:**
  1301â†’Check that priorities prop is defined before mapping. Add default value or null check.
  1302â†’```
  1303â†’
  1304â†’### Step 3: Consolidate (`/flow consolidate`)
  1305â†’
  1306â†’**Purpose:** Fix ONLY the specific errors found during testing (NOT reimplement features)
  1307â†’
  1308â†’**What happens:**
  1309â†’1. Reads error log from `docs/errors-[feature-name].md`
  1310â†’2. Parses each error to identify:
  1311â†’   - Which story (US-XXX) has the error
  1312â†’   - Which step/mavenStep needs to be re-run
  1313â†’   - What the specific error is
  1314â†’3. For each error:
  1315â†’   - Spawns appropriate specialist agent (development, quality, security, etc.)
  1316â†’   - Tells agent exactly what error to fix
  1317â†’   - Waits for fix to be applied
  1318â†’4. Re-tests ONLY the fixed item
  1319â†’5. Marks error as resolved in log
  1320â†’6. Continues until all errors fixed
  1321â†’
  1322â†’**What it does NOT do:**
  1323â†’- Does NOT run full mavenSteps again
  1324â†’- Does NOT re-implement completed features
  1325â†’- Does NOT touch working code
  1326â†’- Only fixes the specific errors identified
  1327â†’
  1328â†’**Example:**
  1329â†’```bash
  1330â†’/flow consolidate task-priority
  1331â†’```
  1332â†’
  1333â†’**Output:**
  1334â†’- Shows which errors are being fixed
  1335â†’- Shows which agent is handling each fix
  1336â†’- Commits each fix separately
  1337â†’- Updates error log as fixes are applied
  1338â†’
  1339â†’### Step 4: Re-test
  1340â†’
  1341â†’After consolidation:
  1342â†’1. Run `/flow test [prd-name]` again
  1343â†’2. Verify all errors are fixed
  1344â†’3. Verify console is clean
  1345â†’4. If errors remain, repeat consolidation
  1346â†’
  1347â†’### Complete Workflow Example
  1348â†’
  1349â†’```bash
  1350â†’# 1. Run development flow
  1351â†’/flow start
  1352â†’
  1353â†’# 2. Test all completed features
  1354â†’/flow test task-priority
  1355â†’
  1356â†’# Output: Testing Complete
  1357â†’# Error Log: docs/errors-task-priority.md

  1360â†’
  1361â†’# 3. Review error log
  1362â†’cat docs/errors-task-priority.md
  1363â†’
  1364â†’# 4. Fix all errors

  1366â†’
  1367â†’# Output:
  1368â†’# Fixing Error 1: TypeError in PrioritySelector
  1369â†’# Spawning quality-agent...
  1370â†’# â†’ Fixed
  1371â†’# Fixing Error 2: Network error in API
  1372â†’# Spawning development-agent...
  1373â†’# â†’ Fixed
  1374â†’# ...
  1375â†’
  1376â†’# 5. Re-test to verify
  1377â†’/flow test task-priority
  1378â†’
  1379â†’# Output: Testing Complete
  1380â†’# Total Errors: 0
  1381â†’# âœ… All features working correctly
  1382â†’```
  1383â†’
  1384â†’### Key Differences: `/flow start` vs `/flow consolidate`
  1385â†’
  1386â†’| Aspect | `/flow start` | `/flow consolidate` |
  1387â†’|--------|---------------|---------------------|
  1388â†’| Purpose | Implement new features | Fix specific errors |
  1389â†’| Input | PRD stories | Error log |
  1390â†’| Runs | Full mavenSteps for each story | Only affected steps |
  1391â†’| Scope | Entire story implementation | Specific error fixes |
  1392â†’| Commits | Full feature commits | Targeted bug fixes |
  1393â†’| Result | New features implemented | Errors resolved |

  1463â†’### Mobile-Specific Features
  1464â†’
  1465â†’#### Offline-First Architecture
  1466â†’All mobile features work offline with automatic sync:
  1467â†’
  1468â†’**Read Pattern:**
  1469â†’1. Check AsyncStorage cache first
  1470â†’2. If fresh (< 5 min), use cached data
  1471â†’3. If missing/stale, fetch from Supabase
  1472â†’4. Update cache and display
  1473â†’
  1474â†’**Write Pattern:**
  1475â†’1. Optimistically update UI immediately
  1476â†’2. If online: Execute immediately
  1477â†’3. If offline: Queue in AsyncStorage
  1478â†’4. When back online: Process queue automatically
  1479â†’
  1480â†’#### Native UI Patterns
  1481â†’Use mobile-specific interactions:
  1482â†’- **Pull-to-refresh** for data reload
  1483â†’- **Swipe actions** for quick actions (delete, complete)
  1484â†’- **Bottom sheets** for options/modals
  1485â†’- **Tab bar** for main navigation
  1486â†’- **Stack navigation** for drilling down
  1487â†’- **Long-press** for context menus
  1488â†’
  1489â†’#### Touch Targets
  1490â†’- **Minimum 44x44 points** for all touch targets (Apple)
  1491â†’- **48x48 dp minimum** for Android
  1492â†’- Adequate spacing between targets
  1493â†’
  1494â†’#### Push Notifications
  1495â†’- Firebase Cloud Messaging for push notifications
  1496â†’- Task assignments, due reminders, status changes
  1497â†’- Background message handling
  1498â†’- Notification channels (Android)

  1719â†’## Common Workflows

  1729â†’2. **Step 3 (refactor):** Structure to feature-based folders
  1730â†’3. **Step 5 (quality):** Remove 'any' types, add @ aliases
  1731â†’4. **Step 7 (dev):** Create API endpoints, connect to database
  1732â†’5. **Step 10 (security):** Add RLS policies, error handling

  1744â†’2. **Step 5 (quality):** Type safety, no 'any' types
  1745â†’3. **Step 6 (refactor):** Move reusable parts to @shared/ui

  1757â†’2. **Step 7 (dev):** Set up Supabase Auth, Firebase integration
  1758â†’3. **Step 8 (security):** Implement auth flow, RLS policies

  1763â†’### Workflow 4: Mobile App (Expo/React Native)
  1764â†’

1â†’# ADR-002: Multi-PRD Architecture
     2â†’
     3â†’**Status:** Accepted
     4â†’
     5â†’**Date:** 2025-01-11
     6â†’
     7â†’## Context
     8â†’
     9â†’**Problem:**
    10â†’- Single monolithic PRD files become unwieldy as projects grow
    11â†’- Different features have different development timelines and priorities
    12â†’- Difficult to track progress across multiple independent features
    13â†’- Merging all features into one flow creates complexity
    14â†’
    15â†’**Observed Issues:**
    16â†’- Large PRD files (1000+ lines) are difficult to navigate and maintain
    17â†’- Changes to one feature block progress on others
    18â†’- No clear separation of concerns between features
    19â†’
    20â†’## Decision
    21â†’
    22â†’**Each feature gets its own PRD JSON file: `docs/prd-[feature-name].json`**
    23â†’
    24â†’The flow command automatically scans for all `prd-*.json` files in `docs/` and processes incomplete ones in order.
    25â†’
    26â†’**Architecture:**
    27â†’```
    28â†’docs/
    29â†’â”œâ”€â”€ prd-user-auth.json          # User authentication feature
    30â†’â”œâ”€â”€ prd-task-priority.json      # Task priority feature
    31â†’â”œâ”€â”€ prd-notifications.json      # Notifications feature
    32â†’â”œâ”€â”€ progress-user-auth.txt      # Auth feature progress log
    33â†’â”œâ”€â”€ progress-task-priority.txt  # Priority feature progress log
    34â†’â””â”€â”€ progress-notifications.txt  # Notifications progress log
    35â†’```
    36â†’
    37â†’**Key Principles:**
    38â†’1. **One PRD per feature**: Each feature has its own PRD file
    39â†’2. **Independent execution**: Features can be developed in parallel
    40â†’3. **Automatic discovery**: Flow command scans for all PRD files
    41â†’4. **Priority ordering**: Stories execute in priority order within each PRD
    42â†’
    43â†’## Consequences
    44â†’
    45â†’**Benefits:**
    46â†’- **Isolation**: Each feature is independent, changes don't affect others
    47â†’- **Parallel development**: Multiple features can be developed simultaneously
    48â†’- **Focused scope**: Each PRD is smaller and more manageable
    49â†’- **Progress tracking**: Clear progress per feature via separate progress files
    50â†’- **Flexible prioritization**: Can work on high-priority features first
    51â†’
    52â†’**Trade-offs:**
    53â†’- **More files**: Multiple PRD and progress files to manage
    54â†’- **Cross-feature dependencies**: Must manage dependencies between features manually
    55â†’- **Potential duplication**: Similar patterns may repeat across PRDs
    56â†’
    57â†’## Alternatives Considered
    58â†’
    59â†’### Alternative 1: Single Monolithic PRD
    60â†’**Description:** One large PRD file containing all features and stories.
    61â†’
    62â†’**Rejected because:**
    63â†’- Becomes unwieldy at 1000+ lines
    64â†’- Changes to one feature affect the entire file
    65â†’- Cannot track progress per feature independently
    66â†’- Slower to parse and load
    67â†’
    68â†’### Alternative 2: Hierarchical PRD Structure
    69â†’**Description:** Parent PRD with child PRDs for each feature.
    70â†’
    71â†’**Rejected because:**
    72â†’- Adds complexity without clear benefits
    73â†’- Parent PRD becomes a synchronization point
    74â†’- More difficult to implement and maintain
    75â†’
    76â†’### Alternative 3: Database-Backed PRD Storage
    77â†’**Description:** Store PRDs in a database instead of files.
    78â†’
    79â†’**Rejected because:**
    80â†’- Adds external dependency
    81â†’- More complex to implement
    82â†’- File-based is simpler and more portable
    83â†’
    84â†’## Implementation
    85â†’
    86â†’**PRD File Naming:**
    87â†’- Format: `prd-[feature-name].json`
    88â†’- Example: `prd-user-auth.json`, `prd-task-priority.json`
    89â†’
    90â†’**Progress File Naming:**
    91â†’- Format: `progress-[feature-name].txt`
    92â†’- Example: `progress-user-auth.txt`, `progress-task-priority.txt`
    93â†’
    94â†’**Flow Execution:**
    95â†’```bash
    96â†’/flow start                    # Process all incomplete PRDs
    97â†’/flow status                   # Show status of all PRDs
    98â†’/flow continue [feature-name]  # Continue specific PRD
    99â†’/flow reset [feature-name]     # Reset specific PRD
   100â†’```
   101â†’
   102â†’**Processing Order:**
   103â†’1. Scan `docs/` for all `prd-*.json` files
   104â†’2. Pick first PRD with incomplete stories (alphabetically by filename)
   105â†’3. Process stories in priority order
   106â†’4. When PRD complete, move to next incomplete PRD
   107â†’5. Continue until all PRDs are complete
   108â†’
   109â†’## References
   110â†’
   111â†’- `.claude/commands/flow.md` - Flow command documentation
   112â†’- `.claude/skills/flow-convert/SKILL.md` - PRD conversion instructions
   113â†’- `.claude/adrs/001-story-level-mcp-assignment.md` - Story-level MCP architecture
   114â†’

1â†’# ADR-003: Feature-Based Folder Structure
     2â†’
     3â†’**Status:** Accepted
     4â†’
     5â†’**Date:** 2025-01-11
     6â†’
     7â†’## Context
     8â†’
     9â†’**Problem:**
    10â†’- Traditional folder structures (components/, pages/, utils/) mix unrelated code
    11â†’- Difficult to find all code related to a specific feature
    12â†’- High coupling between unrelated features
    13â†’- Difficult to delete or refactor features
    14â†’
    15â†’**Observed Issues:**
    16â†’- Components folder becomes a dumping ground with 100+ files
    17â†’- Cross-imports between unrelated features create tight coupling
    18â†’- No clear ownership or boundaries
    19â†’
    20â†’## Decision
    21â†’
    22â†’**Enforce feature-based folder structure with strict isolation rules:**
    23â†’
    24â†’```
    25â†’src/
    26â†’â”œâ”€â”€ app/                    # Entry points, routing
    27â†’â”œâ”€â”€ features/               # Isolated feature modules
    28â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ auth/              # Cannot import from other features
    29â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ api/           # Server actions, API clients
    30â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ components/    # Feature-specific UI
    31â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ hooks/         # Feature-specific hooks
    32â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ types/         # Feature-specific types
    33â†’â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ index.ts       # Public API
    34â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ dashboard/
    35â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ [feature-name]/
    36â†’â”œâ”€â”€ shared/                # Shared code (no feature imports)
    37â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ ui/                # Reusable components
    38â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ api/               # Backend clients
    39â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ utils/             # Utilities
    40â†’```
    41â†’
    42â†’**Key Principles:**
    43â†’1. **Feature isolation**: Features cannot import from other features
    44â†’2. **Shared code only**: Features can import from `@shared/*`
    45â†’3. **Path aliases**: Use `@shared/*`, `@features/*`, `@app/*` (no relative imports)
    46â†’4. **Clear boundaries**: Each feature is self-contained
    47â†’
    48â†’## Consequences
    49â†’
    50â†’**Benefits:**
    51â†’- **Clear ownership**: Each feature has its own directory
    52â†’- **Easy navigation**: Find all code for a feature in one place
    53â†’- **Loose coupling**: Features don't depend on each other
    54â†’- **Easy deletion**: Delete a feature by removing its directory
    55â†’- **Parallel development**: Teams can work on different features without conflicts
    56â†’
    57â†’**Trade-offs:**
    58â†’- **More directories**: More nested structure vs flat structure
    59â†’- **Import verbosity**: Longer import paths (mitigated by path aliases)
    60â†’- ** upfront planning**: Must identify feature boundaries early
    61â†’
    62â†’## Alternatives Considered
    63â†’
    64â†’### Alternative 1: Traditional Component-Based Structure
    65â†’**Description:** Organize by file type (components/, hooks/, utils/).
    66â†’
    67â†’**Rejected because:**
    68â†’- No clear feature boundaries
    69â†’- High coupling between unrelated code
    70â†’- Difficult to find all code for a feature
    71â†’
    72â†’### Alternative 2: Layer-Based Architecture
    73â†’**Description:** Organize by layer (ui/, domain/, infrastructure/).
    74â†’
    75â†’**Rejected because:**
    76â†’- More complex to navigate
    77â†’- Less intuitive for feature development
    78â†’- Still allows cross-feature coupling
    79â†’
    80â†’### Alternative 3: Domain-Driven Design (DDD) Structure
    81â†’**Description:** Organize by domains with bounded contexts.
    82â†’
    83â†’**Rejected because:**
    84â†’- Over-engineering for most applications
    85â†’- Steeper learning curve
    86â†’- Feature-based is simpler and achieves same goals
    87â†’
    88â†’## Implementation
    89â†’
    90â†’**tsconfig.json paths:**
    91â†’```json
    92â†’{
    93â†’  "compilerOptions": {
    94â†’    "paths": {
    95â†’      "@shared/*": ["./src/shared/*"],
    96â†’      "@features/*": ["./src/features/*"],
    97â†’      "@app/*": ["./src/app/*"],
    98â†’      "@/*": ["./src/*"]
    99â†’    }
   100â†’  }
   101â†’}
   102â†’```
   103â†’
   104â†’**ESLint rule for isolation:**
   105â†’```json
   106â†’{
   107â†’  "rules": {
   108â†’    "no-restricted-imports": ["error", {
   109â†’      "patterns": [{
   110â†’        "group": ["@features/**/..", "@features/**/../.."],
   111â†’        "message": "Features cannot import from other features"
   112â†’      }]
   113â†’    }]
   114â†’  }

   117â†’
   118â†’**Import examples:**
   119â†’```typescript

   121â†’import { Button } from '@shared/ui';

   123â†’
   124â†’// âŒ WRONG - Cross-feature import

   126â†’
   127â†’// âœ… CORRECT - Local imports within feature

   130â†’
   131â†’## Migration Process
   132â†’
   133â†’**Step 3 in Maven workflow** handles migration:
   134â†’
   135â†’1. Identify feature boundaries
   136â†’2. Create feature directories (`src/features/[feature-name]/`)
   137â†’3. Move code to appropriate locations
   138â†’4. Update imports to use @ aliases

1â†’# ADR-004: Specialist Agent Coordination via Main Claude Context
     2â†’
     3â†’**Status:** Accepted
     4â†’
     5â†’**Date:** 2025-01-11
     6â†’
     7â†’## Context
     8â†’
     9â†’**Problem:**
    10â†’- Maven Flow requires coordinating multiple specialist agents (development, refactor, quality, security, design)
    11â†’- Each story may require different agents based on its `mavenSteps`
    12â†’- Need to execute steps sequentially with proper state management
    13â†’
    14â†’**Technical Limitation:**
    15â†’From Claude Code CLI documentation:
    16â†’> "The premise of this tool is to spin off a sub-agent that will have the same access to tools as your main agent (**except that it cannot spawn another sub-task**) and reports back the results."
    17â†’
    18â†’**Observed Issues:**
    19â†’- Subagents cannot spawn other subagents
    20â†’- Need a coordination mechanism that respects this limitation
    21â†’- Must ensure each step completes before starting the next
    22â†’
    23â†’## Decision
    24â†’
    25â†’**The `/flow` command (running in main Claude context) coordinates ALL specialist agent spawning directly.**
    26â†’
    27â†’**Architecture:**
    28â†’```
    29â†’Main Claude (with /flow command loaded)
    30â†’  â”‚
    31â†’  â”œâ”€â†’ Task tool â†’ development-agent (Step 1) â†’ Wait â†’ Continue
    32â†’  â”œâ”€â†’ Task tool â†’ refactor-agent (Step 3) â†’ Wait â†’ Continue
    33â†’  â”œâ”€â†’ Task tool â†’ quality-agent (Step 5) â†’ Wait â†’ Continue
    34â†’  â”œâ”€â†’ Task tool â†’ refactor-agent (Step 6) â†’ Wait â†’ Continue
    35â†’  â””â”€â†’ Task tool â†’ security-agent (Step 10) â†’ Wait â†’ Continue
    36â†’```
    37â†’
    38â†’**Key Principles:**
    39â†’1. **Main context coordination**: /flow command runs in main Claude context
    40â†’2. **Sequential execution**: Wait for each agent to complete before spawning next
    41â†’3. **Direct spawning**: Main Claude spawns specialist agents via Task tool
    42â†’4. **State management**: /flow maintains state between agent executions
    43â†’
    44â†’## Consequences
    45â†’
    46â†’**Benefits:**
    47â†’- **Simple architecture**: Clear coordination logic in one place
    48â†’- **Reliable execution**: Sequential execution prevents race conditions
    49â†’- **Easy debugging**: Can see each step's result in order
    50â†’- **No subagent chains**: Respects CLI limitation (subagents can't spawn subagents)
    51â†’
    52â†’**Trade-offs:**
    53â†’- **Long-lived flow**: Flow command must remain loaded throughout execution
    54â†’- **No parallelism**: Steps must execute sequentially (can't parallelize independent steps)
    55â†’- **Manual coordination**: /flow command contains all coordination logic
    56â†’
    57â†’## Alternatives Considered
    58â†’
    59â†’### Alternative 1: flow-iteration Subagent
    60â†’**Description:** Use a flow-iteration subagent to coordinate specialist agents.
    61â†’
    62â†’**Rejected because:**
    63â†’- **Blocked by CLI limitation**: Subagents cannot spawn other subagents
    64â†’- Adds unnecessary indirection
    65â†’- More complex to debug
    66â†’
    67â†’### Alternative 2: Parallel Execution
    68â†’**Description:** Spawn multiple agents simultaneously for independent steps.
    69â†’
    70â†’**Rejected because:**
    71â†’- More complex coordination
    72â†’- Potential race conditions
    73â†’- Difficult to debug failures
    74â†’- No clear benefit for Maven workflow (steps are typically sequential)
    75â†’
    76â†’### Alternative 3: Event-Driven Coordination
    77â†’**Description:** Use events to trigger agent spawns.
    78â†’
    79â†’**Rejected because:**
    80â†’- Over-engineering for this use case
    81â†’- Requires additional infrastructure
    82â†’- Harder to reason about execution order
    83â†’
    84â†’## Implementation
    85â†’
    86â†’**Maven Step to Agent Mapping:**
    87â†’
    88â†’| Maven Step | Agent Type | Task subagent_type | Description |
    89â†’|------------|------------|-------------------|-------------|
    90â†’| 1 | Foundation | development-agent | Import UI with mock data or create from scratch |
    91â†’| 2 | Package Manager | development-agent | Convert npm â†’ pnpm |
    92â†’| 3 | Feature Structure | refactor-agent | Restructure to feature-based folder structure |
    93â†’| 4 | Modularization | refactor-agent | Modularize components >300 lines |
    94â†’| 5 | Type Safety | quality-agent | Type safety - no 'any' types, @ aliases |
    95â†’| 6 | UI Centralization | refactor-agent | Centralize UI components to @shared/ui |
    96â†’| 7 | Data Layer | development-agent | Centralized data layer with backend setup |
    97â†’| 8 | Auth Integration | security-agent | Firebase + Supabase authentication flow |
    98â†’| 9 | MCP Integration | development-agent | MCP integrations |
    99â†’| 10 | Security & Error Handling | security-agent | Security and error handling |
   100â†’| 11 | Mobile Design | design-agent | Professional UI/UX for Expo/React Native (optional) |
   101â†’
   102â†’**Story Processing Flow:**
   103â†’```markdown

   110â†’**Processing:**

   127â†’   â†’ [Waiting for completion]

   129â†’
   130â†’3. Running quality checks...

   133â†’4. Committing changes...

Test SHOP_EMPLOYEE features 111â†’ 112â†’### Testing Checklist 113â†’- [ ] Console is clear (no errors, no warnings) 114â†’- [ ] All API calls succeed (check Network tab) 115â†’- [ ] Test user `revccnt@gmail.com` can log in 116â†’- [ ] All user flows work end-to-end 117â†’- [ ] Role switching works (if multi-role app) 118â†’- [ ] Fix any console errors found 119â†’- [ ] Re-test after fixes 120â†’ 121â†’### Common Console Issues to Fix 122â†’- `ReferenceError`: Variable or function not found 123â†’- `TypeError`: Null/undefined access 124â†’- `Failed to fetch`: API endpoint issues 125â†’- `CORS`: Cross-origin errors 126â†’- `404 / 500`: Backend errors 127â†’- Missing assets or imports 128â†’ 129â†’**Remember:** A clean console = working application. Never mark testing complete with console errors. 130â†’ 131â†’--- 132â†’--- 133â†’ 134â†’## Server Management Pattern (CRITICAL - ALL AGENTS) 135â†’ 136â†’**NEVER stop all Node.js servers.** Always stop only the specific server you intend to stop. 137â†’ 138â†’### The Problem with Broad Server Killing 139â†’ 140â†’**âŒ FORBIDDEN:** 141â†’```bash 142â†’# âŒ Kills ALL Node processes (including other projects!) 143â†’pkill -9 node 144â†’killall node 145â†’taskkill /F /IM node.exe (Windows) 146â†’lsof -ti:3000-9000 | xargs kill -9 147â†’``` 148â†’ 149â†’**Why this is dangerous:** 150â†’- Stops servers from OTHER projects you might have running 151â†’- Stops background processes that may be important 152â†’- Can corrupt database connections 153â†’- Can interrupt other development work 154â†’- Unprofessional and destructive 155â†’ 156â†’### âœ… CORRECT: Stop Specific Server Only 157â†’ 158â†’**Identify and stop ONLY the specific server:** 159â†’ 160â†’#### Option 1: Find the process by port 161â†’```bash 162â†’# List what's running on a specific port 163â†’lsof -ti:3000 # 266â†’ 267â†’// âŒ Emojis as icons 268â†’ğŸ—‘ï¸ 269â†’âœï¸ 270â†’ğŸ”” 271â†’``` 272â†’ 273â†’**âœ… CORRECT - Use Professional Icon Libraries:** 274â†’```tsx 275â†’// âœ… Import from icon libraries 276â†’import { Trash2, Edit, Bell } from 'lucide-react'; 277â†’// or 278â†’import { TrashIcon, PencilIcon, BellIcon } from '@heroicons/react/24/outline'; 279â†’// or 280â†’import { Icon } from '@/shared/ui/icons'; 281â†’ 282â†’// âœ… Use as components 283â†’ 284â†’ 285â†’ 286â†’ 287â†’// âœ… With proper styling 288â†’ 292â†’``` 293â†’ 294â†’**Approved Icon Libraries:** 295â†’- `lucide-react` - Lightweight, consistent, tree-shakeable 296â†’- `@heroicons/react` - Official Tailwind icons 297â†’- `@radix-ui/react-icons` - Radix UI component icons 298â†’- Custom SVG icons in `@/shared/ui/icons` 299â†’ 300â†’**When Creating New Components:** 301â†’1. NEVER use emoji in placeholder text 305â†’ 306â†’**Agent Responsibility:** 307â†’- **quality-agent:** Block any commits with emojis in UI components 308â†’- **development-agent:** Use icon libraries, never emojis 309â†’- **refactor-agent:** Replace emojis with proper icons 310â†’- **design-agent:** Use professional icons for mobile apps 311â†’ 312â†’**Search Pattern to Find Emojis:** 313â†’When reviewing code, search for these emoji patterns: 314â†’- `[\u{1F300}-\u{1F9FF}]` - Unicode emoji ranges 315â†’- Common emoji strings: "ğŸ—‘ï¸", "âœï¸", "ğŸ””", "âœ…", "âŒ", "â³", etc. 316â†’ 317â†’--- 318â†’ 319â†’## Multi-PRD Architecture 320â†’ 321â†’All agents work with **Multi-PRD Architecture**: 322â†’ 323â†’- Each feature has its own PRD file: `docs/prd-[feature-name].json` 324â†’- Each feature has its own progress file: `docs/progress-[feature-name].txt` 325â†’- Agents are invoked with a specific PRD filename to work on 326â†’- Progress files contain learnings and context from previous iterations 327â†’ 328â†’**Working Process:** 329â†’1. **Identify PRD file** - You'll be given a specific PRD filename 330â†’2. **Read PRD** - Use Read tool to load the PRD file 331â†’3. **Read progress** - Use Read tool to load the corresponding progress file for context 332â†’4. **Extract feature name** - Parse the PRD filename to get the feature name 333â†’5. **Research if needed** - Use web-search-prime/web-reader if you're unsure 334â†’6. **Implement** - Complete the step requirements 335â†’7. **Test** - Use appropriate testing methods 336â†’8. **Validate** - Run applicable checks 337â†’9. **Output completion** - Output `STEP_COMPLETE` 338â†’ 339â†’**NOTE:** PRD and progress file updates are handled by the `/flow` command directly. You do NOT need to update them. 340â†’ 341â†’--- 342â†’ 343â†’## Feature-Based Architecture 344â†’ 345â†’Maven Flow enforces this structure: 346â†’ 347â†’``` 348â†’src/ 349â†’â”œâ”€â”€ app/ # Entry points, routing 350â†’â”œâ”€â”€ features/ # Isolated feature modules 351â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ auth/ # Cannot import from other features 352â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ dashboard/ 353â†’â”‚ â””â”€â”€ [feature-name]/ 354â†’â”œâ”€â”€ shared/ # Shared code (no feature imports) 355â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ ui/ # Reusable components 356â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ api/ # Backend clients 357â†’â”‚ â””â”€â”€ utils/ # Utilities 358â†’``` 359â†’ 360â†’**Architecture Rules:** 361â†’- Features â†’ Cannot import from other features 362â†’- Features â†’ Can import from shared/ 363â†’- Shared â†’ Cannot import from features 364â†’- Use `@shared/*`, `@features/*`, `@app/*` aliases (no relative imports) 365â†’ 366â†’--- 367â†’ 368â†’## Quality Standards (All Agents) 369â†’ 370â†’### Import Aliases (ZERO TOLERANCE) 371â†’```typescript 372â†’// âŒ BLOCKED - Relative imports 373â†’import { Button } from '../../../shared/ui/Button' 374â†’import { utils } from '../utils/helpers' 375â†’ 376â†’// âœ… CORRECT - Path aliases 377â†’import { Button } from '@shared/ui/Button' 378â†’import { utils } from '@shared/utils/helpers' 379â†’``` 380â†’ 381â†’### Type Safety (ZERO TOLERANCE for quality-agent, recommended for all) 382â†’```typescript 383â†’// âŒ BLOCKED - 'any' type 384â†’function processData(data: any) { 385â†’ return data.map((item: any) => item.name); 1â†’---
     2â†’name: flow-convert
     3â†’description: "Convert PRDs to prd.json format for next-mavens-flow autonomous execution. Use when you have an existing PRD and need to convert it. Triggers on: convert this prd, turn this into flow format, create prd.json from this, flow json."
     4â†’---
     5â†’
     6â†’# Flow PRD Converter
     7â†’
     8â†’Converts existing PRDs (markdown or text) to the `prd.json` format that next-mavens-flow uses for autonomous execution.
     9â†’
    10â†’---
    11â†’
    12â†’## The Job
    13â†’
    14â†’Take a PRD and convert it to `docs/prd-[feature-name].json`. Create `docs/` folder if it doesn't exist.
    15â†’
    16â†’**Important:** Each feature gets its own PRD JSON file. The flow command will scan for all `prd-*.json` files in `docs/` and process incomplete ones.
    17â†’
    18â†’**CRITICAL:** Each story MUST have its own `mcpTools` object specifying which MCPs to use for each Maven step.
    19â†’
    20â†’---
    21â†’
    22â†’## MCP Tool Assignment (Story-Level, Step-Based)
    23â†’
    24â†’**CRITICAL ARCHITECTURE DECISION:** MCPs are assigned PER STORY PER STEP, not at the PRD level.
    25â†’
    26â†’**SCAN FIRST - Discover Available MCPs:**
    27â†’
    28â†’**BEFORE assigning any MCPs to stories, you MUST:**
    29â†’
    30â†’1. **Check which MCP servers are available** in the current environment
    31â†’2. **Only assign MCPs that actually exist** - don't guess or assume
    32â†’3. **If unsure, leave mcpTools empty** `{}` rather than guessing wrong
    33â†’
    34â†’**How to Discover Available MCPs:**
    35â†’- Check the user's MCP configuration
    36â†’- Ask the user what MCPs they have configured
    37â†’- Look for common MCP patterns in the project (e.g., if using Supabase, check if supabase MCP is set up)
    38â†’
    39â†’**Why Scan First?**
    40â†’- Prevents assigning MCPs that don't exist
    41â†’- Avoids confusion when agents can't find the MCP
    42â†’- Ensures PRD matches actual environment capabilities
    43â†’
    44â†’**Why Story-Level MCP Assignment?**
    45â†’
    46â†’1. **Context Isolation:** Each story has its own specific MCPs, reducing confusion as context grows
    47â†’2. **Precision:** Flow command tells agents exactly which MCPs to use for each step
    48â†’3. **No Hallucination:** Prevents agents from "forgetting" which MCPs are available in large contexts
    49â†’4. **Granular Control:** Different stories and steps can use different MCPs
    50â†’
    51â†’**How to Assign MCPs to Stories:**
    52â†’
    53â†’When creating a PRD JSON, for each story:
    54â†’
    55â†’1. **Identify which Maven steps** the story requires (see Maven Steps Field section below)
    56â†’2. **For each step**, specify which MCPs to use (ONLY from discovered/available MCPs)
    57â†’3. **List MCPs in `mcpTools` object** with step-based keys (e.g., `step1`, `step7`)
    58â†’
    59â†’**Important:** You only specify the MCP **name**, not individual tools. The agent will automatically discover and use the available tools from that MCP.
    60â†’
    61â†’**Common MCPs (verify these are available before using):**
    62â†’
    63â†’| MCP Name | Use For Steps |
    64â†’|----------|--------------|
    65â†’| supabase | 7, 8, 10 (database operations) |
    66â†’| web-search-prime | All steps (research, documentation) |
    67â†’| web-reader | All steps (reading web content) |
    68â†’| chrome-devtools | Testing (browser automation) |
    69â†’| vercel | 9 (deployment) |
    70â†’| wrangler | 9 (deployment) |
    71â†’| figma | 11 (design) |
    72â†’
    73â†’**Example MCP Assignment:**
    74â†’```json
    75â†’{
    76â†’  "mavenSteps": [1, 7],
    77â†’  "mcpTools": {
    78â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
    79â†’    "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"]
    80â†’  }
    81â†’}
    82â†’```
    83â†’
    84â†’This tells the flow:
    85â†’- For Step 1: Use supabase MCP
    86â†’- For Step 7: Use supabase MCP and web-search-prime MCP
    87â†’
    88â†’---
    89â†’
    90â†’## Output Format
    91â†’
    92â†’```json
    93â†’{
    94â†’  "project": "[Project Name]",
    95â†’  "branchName": "flow/[feature-name-kebab-case]",
    96â†’  "description": "[Feature description from PRD]",
    97â†’  "userStories": [
    98â†’    {
    99â†’      "id": "US-001",
   100â†’      "title": "[Story title]",
   101â†’      "description": "As a [user], I want [feature] so that [benefit]",
   102â†’      "acceptanceCriteria": [
   103â†’        "Criterion 1",
   104â†’        "Criterion 2",
   105â†’        "Typecheck passes"
   106â†’      ],
   107â†’      "mavenSteps": [1, 7],
   108â†’      "mcpTools": {
   109â†’        "step1": ["supabase"],
   110â†’        "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"]
   111â†’      },
   112â†’      "priority": 1,
   113â†’      "passes": false,
   114â†’      "notes": ""
   115â†’    }
   116â†’  ]
   117â†’}
   118â†’```
   119â†’
   120â†’**Note:** The `mcpTools` object specifies MCPs for each step using step-based keys. Only list MCP names (e.g., "supabase"), not individual tools. Agents will automatically discover available tools from those MCPs.
   121â†’
   122â†’---
   123â†’
   124â†’**CRITICAL ARCHITECTURAL DECISION:**
   125â†’
   126â†’**Why MCPs are at the STORY level (not PRD level):**
   127â†’
   128â†’1. **Context Isolation:** Each story has its own specific MCPs, reducing confusion as context grows
   129â†’2. **Precision:** Flow command tells agents exactly which MCPs to use for each step
   130â†’3. **No Hallucination:** Prevents agents from "forgetting" which MCPs are available in large contexts
   131â†’4. **Granular Control:** Different stories and steps can use different MCPs
   132â†’
   133â†’**How it works:**
   134â†’
   135â†’When `/flow` processes a story:
   136â†’1. Reads the story's `mavenSteps` array
   137â†’2. For each step, reads the story's `mcpTools` for that step (e.g., `mcpTools.step1`)
   138â†’3. Spawns the specialist agent and tells them: "Use these MCPs: supabase"
   139â†’4. Agent checks if those MCPs are in their available tools
   140â†’5. Agent uses those MCPs (or falls back to standard tools if unavailable)
   141â†’
   142â†’**Example Story with MCP Tools:**
   143â†’
   144â†’```json
   145â†’{
   146â†’  "id": "US-001",
   147â†’  "title": "Add status field to tasks table",
   148â†’  "mavenSteps": [1, 7],
   149â†’  "mcpTools": {
   150â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
   151â†’    "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"]
   152â†’  }
   153â†’}
   154â†’```
   155â†’
   156â†’When processing this story:
   157â†’- Step 1 (development-agent): Told to use supabase MCP
   158â†’- Step 7 (development-agent): Told to use supabase MCP, web-search-prime MCP
   159â†’
   160â†’### Maven Steps Field
   161â†’
   162â†’**CRITICAL:** Each story MUST include a `mavenSteps` array that specifies which Maven workflow steps are required.
   163â†’
   164â†’**Maven Step to Agent Mapping:**
   165â†’
   166â†’| Maven Step | Agent | Description |
   167â†’|------------|-------|-------------|
   168â†’| 1 | development-agent | Foundation - Import UI with mock data or create from scratch |
   169â†’| 2 | development-agent | Package Manager - Convert npm â†’ pnpm |
   170â†’| 3 | refactor-agent | Feature Structure - Restructure to feature-based folder structure |
   171â†’| 4 | refactor-agent | Modularization - Modularize components >300 lines |
   172â†’| 5 | quality-agent | Type Safety - No 'any' types, @ aliases |
   173â†’| 6 | refactor-agent | UI Centralization - Centralize UI components to @shared/ui |
   174â†’| 7 | development-agent | Data Layer - Centralized data layer with backend setup |
   175â†’| 8 | security-agent | Auth Integration - Firebase + Supabase authentication flow |
   176â†’| 9 | development-agent | MCP Integration - MCP integrations (web-search, web-reader, chrome, expo, supabase) |
   177â†’| 10 | security-agent | Security & Error Handling - Security and error handling |
   178â†’| 11 | design-agent | Mobile Design - Professional UI/UX for Expo/React Native (optional) |
   179â†’
   180â†’**Map Maven steps to story types:**
   181â†’
   182â†’| Story Type | Required Maven Steps |
   183â†’|------------|---------------------|
   184â†’| New feature UI from scratch | [1, 3, 5, 6, 10] |
   185â†’| Adding UI component to existing page | [3, 5, 6] |
   186â†’| Database schema changes | [1, 7] |
   187â†’| Backend API/Server actions | [1, 7, 10] |
   188â†’| Authentication flow | [1, 7, 8, 10] |
   189â†’| MCP integration | [9] |
   190â†’| Refactoring existing code | [4, 5] |
   191â†’| Full feature (schema + backend + UI) | [1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 10] |
   192â†’
   193â†’**Example assignments:**
   194â†’```json
   195â†’// Database migration story
   196â†’{
   197â†’  "id": "US-001",
   198â†’  "title": "Add status column to tasks table",
   199â†’  "mavenSteps": [1, 7],  // Foundation + Data layer
   200â†’  "mcpTools": {
   201â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
   202â†’    "step7": ["supabase"]
   203â†’  }
   204â†’}
   205â†’
   206â†’// UI component story
   207â†’{
   208â†’  "id": "US-002",
   209â†’  "title": "Add status badge to task cards",
   210â†’  "mavenSteps": [5, 6],  // Type safety + UI centralization
   211â†’  "mcpTools": {}
   212â†’}
   213â†’
   214â†’// Full feature story
   215â†’{
   216â†’  "id": "US-003",
   217â†’  "title": "Create user profile page",
   218â†’  "mavenSteps": [1, 3, 5, 6, 7, 10],  // Most steps
   219â†’  "mcpTools": {
   220â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
   221â†’    "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"],
   222â†’    "step10": ["web-search-prime"]
   223â†’  }
   224â†’}
   225â†’```
   226â†’
   227â†’---
   228â†’
   229â†’## Story Size: The Number One Rule
   230â†’
   231â†’**Each story must be completable in ONE flow iteration (one context window).**
   232â†’
   233â†’The flow spawns fresh each iteration with no memory of previous work. If a story is too big, the context fills before finishing and produces broken code.
   234â†’
   235â†’### Right-sized stories:
   236â†’- Add a database column and migration
   237â†’- Add a UI component to an existing page
   238â†’- Update a server action with new logic
   239â†’- Add a filter dropdown to a list
   240â†’
   241â†’### Too big (split these):
   242â†’- "Build the entire dashboard" â†’ Split into: schema, queries, UI components, filters
   243â†’- "Add authentication" â†’ Split into: schema, middleware, login UI, session handling
   244â†’- "Refactor the API" â†’ Split into one story per endpoint or pattern
   245â†’
   246â†’**Rule of thumb:** If you cannot describe the change in 2-3 sentences, it's too big.
   247â†’
   248â†’---
   249â†’
   250â†’## Story Ordering: Dependencies First
   251â†’
   252â†’Stories execute in priority order. Earlier stories must not depend on later ones.
   253â†’
   254â†’**Correct order:**
   255â†’1. Schema/database changes (migrations)
   256â†’2. Server actions / backend logic
   257â†’3. UI components that use the backend
   258â†’4. Dashboard/summary views that aggregate data
   259â†’
   260â†’**Wrong order:**
   261â†’1. UI component (depends on schema that does not exist yet)
   262â†’2. Schema change
   263â†’
   264â†’---
   265â†’
   266â†’## Acceptance Criteria: Must Be Verifiable
   267â†’
   268â†’Each criterion must be something that can be CHECKED.
   269â†’
   270â†’### Good criteria (verifiable):
   271â†’- "Add `status` column to tasks table with default 'pending'"
   272â†’- "Filter dropdown has options: All, Active, Completed"
   273â†’- "Clicking delete shows confirmation dialog"
   274â†’- "Typecheck passes"
   275â†’
   276â†’### Bad criteria (vague):
   277â†’- "Works correctly"
   278â†’- "User can do X easily"
   279â†’- "Good UX"
   280â†’
   281â†’### Always include:
   282â†’```
   283â†’"Typecheck passes"
   284â†’```
   285â†’
   286â†’For testable stories:
   287â†’```
   288â†’"Tests pass"
   289â†’```
   290â†’
   291â†’### For UI stories:
   292â†’```
   293â†’"Verify in browser"
   294â†’```
   295â†’
   296â†’---
   297â†’
   298â†’## Conversion Rules
   299â†’
   300â†’1. **Each user story** becomes one JSON entry
   301â†’2. **IDs**: Sequential (US-001, US-002, etc.)
   302â†’3. **Priority**: Based on dependency order, then document order
   303â†’4. **All stories**: `passes: false` and empty `notes`
   304â†’5. **branchName**: Derive from feature name, kebab-case, prefixed with `flow/`
   305â†’6. **Always add**: "Typecheck passes" to every story's acceptance criteria
   306â†’7. **CRITICAL**: Add `mavenSteps` array to each story - see Maven Steps Field section above
   307â†’8. **CRITICAL**: Add `mcpTools` object to each story - only list MCP names, not individual tools
   308â†’
   309â†’---
   310â†’
   311â†’## Splitting Large PRDs
   312â†’
   313â†’If a PRD has big features, split them:
   314â†’
   315â†’**Original:**
   316â†’> "Add user notification system"
   317â†’
   318â†’**Split into:**
   319â†’1. US-001: Add notifications table to database
   320â†’2. US-002: Create notification service for sending notifications
   321â†’3. US-003: Add notification bell icon to header
   322â†’4. US-004: Create notification dropdown panel
   323â†’5. US-005: Add mark-as-read functionality
   324â†’6. US-006: Add notification preferences page
   325â†’
   326â†’Each is one focused change completable independently.
   327â†’
   328â†’---
   329â†’
   330â†’## Example
   331â†’
   332â†’**Input PRD:**
   333â†’```markdown

   335â†’
   336â†’Add ability to mark tasks with different statuses.

# Maven Flow Codebase Exploration Report

## Overview
This document provides a comprehensive summary of the Maven Flow codebase structure, focusing on hooks, PRD structure, command architecture, memory system, and validation patterns.

---

## 1. Hook Structure

### Current Hook Locations

**`.claude/hooks/` (Root level):**

pre-task-flow-validation.js
```

**`.claude/maven-flow/hooks/` (Project-specific):**
```
post-tool-use-quality.sh
stop-comprehensive-check.sh
```

### Hook Configuration

**Main configuration**: `/home/ken/github/.claude/maven-flow/.claude/settings.json`
```json
{
  "hooks": {
    "PostToolUse": [
      {
        "matcher": "Write|Edit|MultiEdit",
        "hooks": [
          {
            "type": "command",
            "command": "bash \"$CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR/.claude/maven-flow/hooks/post-tool-use-quality.sh\"",
            "once": false
          }
        ]
      }
    ],
    "Stop": [
      {
        "matcher": "",
        "hooks": [
          {
            "type": "command",
            "command": "bash \"$CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR/.claude/maven-flow/hooks/stop-comprehensive-check.sh\"",
            "once": false
          }
        ]
      }
    ]
  }
}
```

### Pre-Task Flow Validation Hook

**File**: `/home/ken/github/.claude/hooks/pre-task-flow-validation.js`

**Purpose**: Validates PRD files exist before spawning Maven Flow specialist agents.

**Validates for these agents:**
- development-agent
- refactor-agent
- quality-agent
- security-agent
- design-agent

**Validation logic:**
1. Checks if `docs/` directory exists
2. Scans for PRD files (`prd-*.json`)
3. Returns exit code 3 if PRD validation fails (blocks the tool)

### Post-Tool-Use Quality Hook

**File**: `/home/ken/github/.claude/maven-flow/hooks/post-tool-use-quality.sh`

**Purpose**: Runs after every Write/Edit operation to validate quality standards.

**File types checked**:
- TypeScript/TSX, JavaScript/JSX, CSS, SCSS, SASS, Less files

**Zero Tolerance (BLOCKING) violations:**
1. **Any Types** - `: any`, `: any[]`, `: any<`, `as any`, `Promise<any>`, `Record<any`, `<T = any>`
2. **Gradients** - `linear-gradient`, `radial-gradient`, `conic-gradient` in CSS and inline styles

**Warning-level violations:**
1. Relative imports (should use `@` aliases)
2. Large components (>300 lines for TSX/JSX/Vue)
3. Direct API calls (should use data layer)
4. UI component duplication (should use `@shared/ui`)

**Security checks:**
- Exposed API keys
- Hardcoded passwords
- Hardcoded secrets
- Google tokens

### Stop Comprehensive Check Hook

**File**: `/home/ken/github/.claude/maven-flow/hooks/stop-comprehensive-check.sh`

**Purpose**: Runs before completing work - validates all quality standards comprehensively.

**Checks executed:**
1. **Large Components** - Find all TSX/JSX files >300 lines
2. **Type Safety** - Count all variations of 'any' types
3. **Gradients** - Count gradients in CSS, SCSS, and TSX/JSX
4. **Import Paths** - Count relative imports
5. **Feature Isolation** - Check for cross-feature imports via ESLint
6. **UI Component Duplication** - Check for duplicate Button components
7. **Security Scan** - Check for exposed secrets

**Exit codes:**
- Exit 2: Blocking violations found
- Exit 1: Non-blocking issues found
- Exit 0: All checks passed

---

## 2. PRD Structure and Format

### PRD File Locations
- **Markdown PRDs**: `docs/prd-[feature-name].md`
- **JSON PRDs**: `docs/prd-[feature-name].json`

### PRD JSON Schema

**File**: `/home/ken/github/.claude/shared/prd-json-schema.md`

**Structure**:
```json
{
  "project": "string - Project name from PRD title",
  "branchName": "string - Git branch name in format: flow/feature-name-kebab-case",
  "description": "string - Brief one-line description of the feature",
  "memorialFile": "string - Path to memorial file: docs/memorial-feature-name.txt",
  "relatedMemorials": ["string - Paths to related memorial files"],
  "userStories": [
    {
      "id": "string - User story ID: US-001, US-002, etc.",
      "title": "string - Short title describing the story",
      "description": "string - Full user story: As a [user], I want [feature] so that [benefit]",
      "acceptanceCriteria": ["string - Verifiable criterion 1", ...],
      "mavenSteps": [number, number],  // Array of step numbers (1-10)
      "mcpTools": {
        "step1": ["mcp-name-1", "mcp-name-2"],
        "step7": ["mcp-name-3"]
      },
      "priority": number,  // Must be >= 1
      "passes": boolean,   // Always false initially
      "notes": "string"
    }
  ]
}
```

### Key PRD Fields

| Field | Type | Required | Description |
|-------|------|----------|-------------|
| `project` | string | Yes | Project name from PRD title |
| `branchName` | string | Yes | Git branch name for this feature |
| `description` | string | Yes | One-line summary |
| `memorialFile` | string | Yes | Path to feature's memorial file |
| `relatedMemorials` | array | Yes | List of related memorial file paths |
| `userStories` | array | Yes | Array of story objects (min 1) |
| `schemaVersion` | number | Yes | Version of PRD JSON schema (currently 1) |

### User Story Fields

| Field | Type | Required | Description |
|-------|------|----------|-------------|
| `id` | string | Yes | Story identifier (US-001, etc.) |
| `title` | string | Yes | Short descriptive title |
| `description` | string | Yes | Full user story format |
| `acceptanceCriteria` | array | Yes | List of verifiable criteria |
| `mavenSteps` | array | Yes | Array of step numbers (1-10) |
| `mcpTools` | object | Yes | Step-based MCP mapping (or `{}`) |
| `priority` | number | Yes | Priority order (lower = higher) |
| `passes` | boolean | Yes | Story completion status |
| `notes` | string | Yes | Implementation notes |

### Maven Steps Reference

| Step | Agent | Purpose |
|------|-------|---------|
| 1 | development | Foundation/UI from scratch |
| 2 | development | Package manager changes (npmâ†’pnpm) |
| 3 | refactor | Feature structure changes |
| 4 | refactor | Modularization (>300 lines) |
| 5 | quality | Type safety enforcement (no 'any' types) |
| 6 | refactor | UI centralization (@shared/ui) |
| 7 | development | Data layer/backend implementation |
| 8 | security | Authentication/authorization integration |
| 9 | development | MCP integration |
| 10 | security | Security hardening & error handling |

### MCP Tools Format

**Rules:**
- Only list MCP **server names**, not individual tools
- Use step-based keys: "step1", "step7", etc.
- Use empty object `{}` if no MCPs needed

**Common MCPs:**
| MCP Name | When to Use |
|----------|-------------|
| `supabase` | Steps 1, 7, 8, 10 - Database/auth operations |
| `web-search-prime` | All steps - Web searches |
| `chrome-devtools` | Testing - Browser automation |
| `4-5v-mcp` | All steps - Image analysis |

## 3. Bin Command Structure

**Location**: `/home/ken/github/bin/`

**Main Commands:**

| Command | File | Purpose |
|---------|------|---------|
| `flow` | flow.sh | Main flow orchestrator (start, status, continue, reset) |
| `flow-prd` | flow-prd.sh | PRD generator terminal forwarder |
| `flow-convert` | flow-convert.sh | Convert markdown PRDs to JSON format |
| `flow-status` | flow-status.sh | Show current PRD status |
| `flow-sync` | flow-sync.sh | Sync maven-flow wrapper across machines |
| `flow-update` | flow-update.sh | Update Maven Flow |
| `flow-uninstall-global` | flow-uninstall-global.sh | Uninstall Maven Flow globally |
| `flow-install-global` | flow-install-global.sh | Install Maven Flow globally |
| `maven-flow-wrapper` | maven-flow-wrapper.sh | Wrapper for local maven-flow execution |

### flow.sh (Main Command)

**Location**: `/home/ken/github/bin/flow.sh`

**Parameters:**
```
flow start [max-iterations]  - Start flow (default: 100 iterations)
flow status                  - Show current status

```

**Key Features:**
- Story completion detection using story stats
- Session management with `.flow-session` file
- Progress tracking with story counts
- Real-time streaming of Claude output
- Exit code 2 for max iterations reached

---

## 4. Memory-Related Files

### Memory File Locations

The Maven Flow memory system is designed to store implementation knowledge at multiple levels:

**Expected Structure:**
```

## 5. MCP Validation and Path Handling

### MCP Validation in PRD Conversion

**Location**: `/home/ken/github/.claude/skills/flow-convert/SKILL.md`

**Critical Architecture Decision: MCPs are assigned PER STORY PER STEP, not at the PRD level.**

**Validation Process:**

**BEFORE assigning MCPs to stories, you MUST:**
1. **Check which MCP servers are available** in the current environment
2. **Only assign MCPs that actually exist** - don't guess or assume
3. **If unsure, leave mcpTools empty** `{}` rather than guessing wrong

**How to Discover Available MCPs:**
- Check the user's MCP configuration
- Ask the user what MCPs they have configured
- Look for common MCP patterns in the project
- Check for MCP tools in available agent definitions

**Why Scan First?**
- Prevents assigning MCPs that don't exist
- Avoids confusion when agents can't find the MCP
- Ensures PRD matches actual environment capabilities

3. **Path resolution** - Cross-PRD memory loading needs robust path resolution
4. **Hook configuration** - Ensure hooks are properly loaded in both main and maven-flow subdirectories
